photo.description: An architectural landmark, the Wainwright Building is a masterpiece of Chicago School architect Louis Sullivan. The 1891 building now serves as a state office building, with annexes added to it.
photo.tags: cityscape downtown commercialbuilding historical architecture chicagoschool louissullivan officebuilding stlouis missouri 2004
photo.title: Wainwright Building, St. Louis

photo.description: This 1892 Louis Sullivan skyscraper was one of the first in the world. It is one of three Sullivan structures in St. Louis.

photo.title: Wainwright Building

photo.description: An exterior detail of Adler & Sullivan's Wainwright Building, St. Louis, MO
photo.tags: missouri saintlouis stlouis architecture officebuilding wainwrightbuilding wainwrightstateofficebuilding dankmaradler louishenrisullivan louishsullivan adlersullivan skyscraper chicagoschool landmark nationalhistoriclandmark dioramasky
photo.title: Wainwright Building

photo.description: Louis Sullivan's Wainwright Building St. Louis, MO From Wikipedia: The Wainwright Building is a 10-story red-brick landmark office building in downtown St. Louis, Missouri. Built in 1891 and designed by Dankmar Adler and Louis Sullivan, it is among the first skyscrapers in the world. Sullivan used a steel frame and applied his intricate terra cotta ornament in vertical bands to emphasize the height of the building. The ornamentation for the building is adopted from Notre-Dame de Reims in France. After a period of neglect, the building now houses Missouri state offices and is well maintained. It's named for local financier Ellis Wainwright; Sullivan also designed the Wainwright Tomb in St. Louis's Bellefontaine Cemetery for his wife Charlotte Dickson Wainwright.
photo.tags: louissullivan sullivan architecture earlyskyscraper stlouis wainwrightbuilding prairieschool
photo.title: Wainwright detail

photo.description: Louis Sullivan's Wainwright Building St. Louis, MO From Wikipedia: The Wainwright Building is a 10-story red-brick landmark office building in downtown St. Louis, Missouri. Built in 1891 and designed by Dankmar Adler and Louis Sullivan, it is among the first skyscrapers in the world. Sullivan used a steel frame and applied his intricate terra cotta ornament in vertical bands to emphasize the height of the building. The ornamentation for the building is adopted from Notre-Dame de Reims in France. After a period of neglect, the building now houses Missouri state offices and is well maintained. It's named for local financier Ellis Wainwright; Sullivan also designed the Wainwright Tomb in St. Louis's Bellefontaine Cemetery for his wife Charlotte Dickson Wainwright.
photo.tags: louissullivan sullivan architecture earlyskyscraper stlouis prairieschool wainwrightbuilding
photo.title: Wainwright Landmark Marker

photo.description: The intriguing Wainwright Tomb is one of three Louis Sullivan structures in St. Louis. It was commissioned for the wife of the same Wainwright Sullivan built the downtown skyscraper for, and several other significant people are buried in Bellefontaine Cemetery.

photo.title: Wainwright Building

photo.description: The Instrument of Surrender terminating the Second World War was signed, on this spot aboard the USS Missouri, September 2, 1945, while she lay at anchor in Tokyo Bay. At 9:04, the Japanese representatives, Mamoru Shicemitsu, the Japanese Foreign Minister, and General Yoshijiro Umezu, the Chief of Staff, Japanese Army Headquarters, signed the instrument of their country's surrender. At 9:08, General of the Army Douglas Macarthur, the Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers, signed for all the Nations joined in the war against Japan. He was accompanied by Lieutenant General Jonathan W. Wainwright, the Commanding General at the Fall of Corregidor in 1942, and by Lieutenant General Arthur Percival, the Commanding General at the Fall of Singapore in the same year. At 9:12, Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz signed for the United States. He was accompanied by Admiral William F. Halsey, Commander of the United States Third Fleet and by Rear Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Deputy Chief of Staff to Admiral Nimitz. Representatives of the other Allied Nations the signed, completing the ceremony of surrender. The USS-Missouri (BB-63), known as the Mighty Mo or Big Mo, is a United States Navy Iowa-class battleship. Ordered in 1940 and commissioned in 1944, it was the last battleship built by the United States. In the Pacific Theater, she fought in the battles of Iwo Jima and Okinawa, before serving as the site of the surrender of the Empire of Japan to end World War II. She fought in the Korean War from 1950 to 1953, before being decommissioned in 1955. Reactivated and modernized in 1984 as part of the 600-ship Navy plan, the Missouri provided fire support during Operation Desert Storm in 1991. Finally decommissioned in 1992, she remained on the Naval Register until her name was struck in 1995. In 1998, she became a museum ship moored at Foxtrot 5 Pier on Ford Island in Pearl Harbor. Pearl Harbor, U.S. Naval Base National Historic District National Register #66000940 (1966)
photo.tags: instrumentofsurrender generalyoshijiroumezu douglasmacarthur generaldouglasmacarthur ussmissouri battleshipmissouri mightymo bigmo fordisland pearlharbor honolulu honolulucounty oahu hawaii ussmissourimemorial bb63 battleship unitedstatesnavy historicdistrict nationalhistoricdistrict usnationalregisterofhistoricplaces nrhp nationalregisterofhistoricplaces landmark
photo.title: O'ahu - Honolulu - Pearl Harbor: USS Missouri - Umero and MacArthur sign the Instrument of Surrender

photo.description: Louis Sullivan's Wainwright Building St. Louis, MO From Wikipedia: The Wainwright Building is a 10-story red-brick landmark office building in downtown St. Louis, Missouri. Built in 1891 and designed by Dankmar Adler and Louis Sullivan, it is among the first skyscrapers in the world. Sullivan used a steel frame and applied his intricate terra cotta ornament in vertical bands to emphasize the height of the building. The ornamentation for the building is adopted from Notre-Dame de Reims in France. After a period of neglect, the building now houses Missouri state offices and is well maintained. It's named for local financier Ellis Wainwright; Sullivan also designed the Wainwright Tomb in St. Louis's Bellefontaine Cemetery for his wife Charlotte Dickson Wainwright.

photo.description: Louis Sullivan's Wainwright Building St. Louis, MO From Wikipedia: The Wainwright Building is a 10-story red-brick landmark office building in downtown St. Louis, Missouri. Built in 1891 and designed by Dankmar Adler and Louis Sullivan, it is among the first skyscrapers in the world. Sullivan used a steel frame and applied his intricate terra cotta ornament in vertical bands to emphasize the height of the building. The ornamentation for the building is adopted from Notre-Dame de Reims in France. After a period of neglect, the building now houses Missouri state offices and is well maintained. It's named for local financier Ellis Wainwright; Sullivan also designed the Wainwright Tomb in St. Louis's Bellefontaine Cemetery for his wife Charlotte Dickson Wainwright.
photo.tags: louissullivan sullivan architecture earlyskyscraper prairieschool wainwrightbuilding stlouis
photo.title: The Wainwright

photo.description: The Wainwright Building in St. Louis, a national landmark (1891). It was the first Adler & Sullivan building to completely use iron and steel framing. It was built for Ellis Wainwright, a wealthy brewer, to house the St. Louis Brewers Association. It was the second major commission for Adler & Sullivan outside of Chicago's Auditorium Building. The vertical bands on the building emphasize its height, and while it wasn't the first tall office building, it is considered by some to be the first true skyscraper.
photo.tags: louissullivan chicagoschool dankmaradler adlersullivan stlouis missouri 1890s
photo.title: Wainwright Building
